title: brexit deal brussels theresa may jeremy hunt
story: The Foreign Secretary said European leaders must be flexible to get a deal which can make it through Parliament.And Brexiteers threaten a day of reckoningRemainers manage to keep Britain in the EU past the March  deadline.This afternoon Theresa May will make a public appeal to the EU to fix the existing deal so the UK doesnt get trapped in the Irish backstop.Shes expected to say: The decisions that the European Union makes over the next few days will have a big impact on the outcome of the vote.Mr Hunt told the BBC: History will judge both sides very badlywe get this wrong.We want to remain the best of friends with the EU. That means getting this agreement through in a way that doesnt inject poison into our relations for many years to come.Thats what the UK has said we want to do, its what most people in the UK want and feel very strongly about.But it does need the EU also to be flexible in these negotiations and understand that we now have a very, very clear ask.We know what it would take to get a deal through the House of Commons, and that is for a signicant change to allow the Attorney General to change his advice to the Government and say we couldnt be trapped in a customs union forever.Frankly I think future generations,this ends in acrimony, will say that the EU got this moment wrong. And I really hope they dont.Government law chief Geoffrey Cox has run into trouble during talks in Brussels after EU officials rejected his demands for a fix to the backstop.Ex-Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab last night warned that voters will revolt against any attempt to wreck our EU exit.Appearing on Question Time, he blasted: Are we going to effectively be put in the position that it’s either a bad deal or no Brexit Frankly, I thinkthere’s that kind of establishment stitch-up to try and frustrate the process of Brexit, there will be a day of reckoning with the voters.Because I think the one thing people expect is to get Brexit done and dusted on March .MPs will vote for a second time on Mrs Mays deal on Tuesday.If the withdrawal agreement is defeated, they will then have a choice between a No Deal Brexit and delaying our departure date.Today George Eustice, who quit as a minister over Brexit, insisted the country is ready to leave without a deal in three weeks time.He said Britain and the EU could enter a nine-month transition period where the UK kept European rules to avoid interrupting trade.The two sides would then use that time to put permanent arrangements in place for a free-trade agreement.John Major and Gordon Brown have both demanded an extension of the Article  process to consult the public on how to carry out Brexit.In separate interventions, they both suggested a three-month delay wouldnt be enough for MPs to reach agreement on a deal.Mr Brown told Sky News: I regret to say this but Parliament has, unfortunately, proved itself totally incapable of resolving the Brexit issue.The only way to deal with this impasse is to have an extension of the negotiating period.But an extension for three months would be inadequate because it would just be the same old squabbling.And Sir John wrote in a letter to The Times: Leaving the EU would be turbulent.But logic, common sense and the national interest suggest that an extension of one year would give us the time to depart with dignity and grace, and in good order.Of the other two living ex-PMs, Tony Blair backs a second referendum while David Cameron has remained loyal to Theresa May and supports her deal.Theresa May is fighting to fix her Brexit deal

title: theresa may brexit speech deal vote
story: In a last-ditch bid to win over rebel MPs, the PM claimed the UK faces months more spent arguing about Brexitthe deal is defeated on Tuesday next week.And she hit out at Remainers who want to overturn the referendum result.Speaking in Grimsby this afternoon, Mrs May said: Next week members of Parliament in Westminster face a crucial choice - whether to back the Brexit deal or reject it.Reject it, and no one knows what will happen - we may not leave the EU for many months, we may leave without the protections the deal provides, we may never leave at all.The only certainty would be ongoing uncertainty - months more spent arguing about Brexit when we should be improving our NHS, our schools and our communities.She added: Parliament gave the decision to leave or remain in the European Union to you.The result was close but it was clear - the decision was to leave and that is what we must do. Brexit does not belong to MPs in Parliament, it belongs to the whole country. It belongs to the people who voted for it and want to see it implemented so we can all move on to a prosperous future.And that more prosperous future also belongs to those who voted against Brexit and who expect politicians to make reasonable compromises to bring our country back together.The Prime Minister also took aim at the EU and warned Brussels will have to take its share of responsibilityher efforts fail.She said: “Just as MPs will face a big choice next week, the EU has to make a choice too.“We are both participants in this process. It is in the European interest for the UK to leave with a deal.“We are working with them but the decisions that the European Union makes over the next few days will have a big impact on the outcome of the vote.”Mrs May insisted that it needs just one more push to address the final, specic concerns of our Parliament.Blasting the possibility of a delay which would prolong the uncertainty, she said: That might lead to a form of Brexit that does not match up to what people voted for.And a delay could lead to something  – a second Brexit referendum. The chances of that have increased since Jeremy Corbyn said he would back one.The PM said staying in the EU would be a political failure which lets down the .million people who voted to back Brexit .She added: My message to those MPs who agree with me that we should not risk that is simple - the only certain way to avoid it is to back the deal the Government has secured with EU on Tuesday.Repeating the phrase lets get it done, Mrs May concluded: The British people have moved on, they want us to get it done. What people want is for us to do this and do it now.MPs will vote on whether or not to approve the deal on Tuesday, after rejecting it first time round in January.If they defeat the deal they will then have the choice between a No Deal Brexit on March , or a delay to the Article  process taking us out of the EU.Attorney General Geoffrey Cox has been in Brussels this week trying to secure a fix to the deal which can win over enough Tory MPs in next weeks vote.But he came away empty-handed as the EU played hardball - raising the possibility of a second humiliating Commons defeat.Labour MP Margaret Beckett, a backer of the Peoples Vote campaign, said today: The Brexit process has become a national humiliation and nowhere is this clearer than in position of the Prime Minister herself.“Today she has been left as a supplicant to the EU, begging them to reverse and revise an agreement of which she herself was the principal author and which she hailed as a triumph for her diplomacy only a matter of weeks ago.

title: eu brexit deal michel barnier backstop
story: Eurocrat Michel Barnier tabled an offer that would allow Britain to quit the customs union rather than being trapped in the backstop.But the plan would see Northern Ireland staying tied to the EU - effectively creating a border inside the United Kingdom.The offer is almost identical to a proposal which was rejected by Theresa May months ago.She has also consistently said one of her major priorities remains keeping the UK intact and she would never consider a deal that would split it apart.Critics claimed the move proved the EU isnt serious about helping the PM get her deal across the line next week.Mrs Mays officials have been locked in talks with Brussels ever since the deal was voted down by MPs in January.Brexiteers have warned they wont back the withdrawal agreement unless the backstop, which keeps the UK in the customs union to avoid a hard border in Ireland, is fixed.Mr Barnier, the EUs chief Brexit envoy, said today that he had offered legally binding changes to the PMs team.One part of the offer would give more force to existing proposals which let us leave the backstopfuture trade talks break down.But the other would see Great Britain quit the customs union while Northern Ireland stays in, keeping the border open while creating a new border in the Irish Sea.The idea of a Northern Ireland-only backstop was already shot down by Mrs May in talks last year.Mr Barnier tweeted: UK will not be forced into customs union against its will.The EU will continue working intensively over the coming days to ensure that the UK leaves the EU with an agreement.But furious Brexiteers hit back - David Davis ex-chief of staff Stewart Jackson raged: The EU are still playing games.The DUP also rejected the idea because it would not respect the constitutional and economic integrity of the UK.Even pro-Remain MPs were annoyed - Scottish Tory Paul Masterton said: An exclusively NI backstop would be far more unacceptable. We now have the EU presenting old solutions it knows we wont accept, which is exactly what its been criticising UK for doing.Attorney General Geoffrey Cox is seeking a fix to the backstop which would allow him to change his legal advice.He ed from Brussels empty-handed earlier this week but talks will continue over the weekend.

title: amber rudd calling diane abbott
story: NewsopinionAmber Rudd calling Diane Abbott coloured must not be swept under the carpetMirror columnist Eva Simpson has written an open letter to the Work and Pensions Secretary urging her to think long and hardShareByEva Simpson:,  MAR NewsopinionAmber Rudd called Dianne Abbott coloured "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDear Amber, As you quickly realised, within hours of clumsily saying “coloured” to describe your fellow MP Diane Abbott, the word is outdated, offensive and revealing. I’m pleased that rather than trying to justy its use, you moved quickly to apologise and spoke of being “mortied” you said it. No doubt your team are keen to draw a line under things and move on. But many aren’t as keen to quickly sweep it under the carpet and pretend nothing has happened. As someone who was once married to a prominent journalist, you of all people should know the power of words. It worries me a Cabinet Minister - one who was previously in charge of a Home Office that was presided over the Windrush scandal which saw Caribbeans wrong deported and denied legal rights - can so casually bandy around a term like coloured.   I cringed when I heard you say it in your BBC interview with Jeremy Vine. It’s the kind of language you might expect to hear from a great-grandad who doesn’t know any better. And it makes me think,you can use that word publicly, without skipping a beat, what kind of language do you use in private  In making your wider point, ironically in defence of Diane, you said it was awful that “black and minority ethnic people suffer in this way”. You know what, I feel using terms like “minority ethnic” to describe people are just as isive. They have become an acceptable way of reminding people that they are dferent, not the norm and by extension less than what is considered the mainstream.  BAME and BME are politically correct acronyms that sprung up in recent years to allow politicians, squeamish about using the word black, to have a get out of jail free card. But can you tell me what it actually means  Is it Black and Minority Ethnic  If so, where do Asian people fit into this description. Or is it Black, Asian and Minority Ethnic. In this case, who are the minority ethnic people that we are constantly trying to point to as being dferent  You come from the party of Anne Marie Morris, the Conservative MP who in  used the N-word in during a discussion about Brexit and Boris Johnson who has referred to black people as “piccaninnies” and having “watermelon smiles”. As I heard someone say on the radio, this has to be a “teachable moment”. It can’t simply be yesterday’s news.

title: brexit eu chief michel barnier
story: NewsBrexit: EU chief Michel Barnier sparks anger by revealing his offer to UKThe Brussels chief negotiator said Britain - but not Northern Ireland - could leave the Irish backstopShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical CorrespondentDan BloomOnline Political EditorOliver Milne:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsMichel Barnier of the EU unveiled his offer - but is it actually anything new  "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEU chief Michel Barnier tonight unveiled an offer to the UK on Brexit just four days before a crucial vote. The Brussels chief negotiator took the unprecedented step of publicly tweeting his plan for a compromise on the Irish backstop. Theresa May has for weeks being trying to rework the backstop - a clause in the -page Brexit deal that could trap the UK under EU customs rules. She wanted either a way to quit the backstop, a time limit, or alternative arrangements to replace it. Tonight Mr Barnier said the EU would commit to letting the UK exit the backstop - but only one part of it, a shared customs union with the EU. That means the other provisions would have to stay - a move critics say will ide Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK.  A DUP source tonight said they would not back any deal which saw a customs border established in the Irish Sea. Weve been clear from the very start, anything which would see Northern Ireland treated separately from the UK will not get our support and we will be reiterating that to the PM A Tory Brexiteer told the Financial Times: Do they think we are stupid  Tory MP Paul Masterson tweeted: An exclusively NI backstop would be far more unacceptable. Round in circles we go.   And its something the current draft enables anyway . So we now have the EU presenting old solutions it knows we wont accept, which is exactly what its been criticising UK for doing. Askedthey had any reaction to the EUs offer, a Brexiteer source said: Not really. They’re laughable. We laugh at them. Mr Barnier issued the ultimatum as he slammed the blame game just hours after Theresa May appeared to blame the EU in a major speech. Mrs May urged EU leaders to make just one more push and her Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt warned them not to inject poison into the UK-EU relationship. But Mr Barnier told reporters in Brussels: The EU stands united. We are not interested in the blame game. We are still working.  It came as Theresa May attempted to pin the blame for the Brexit chaos on the EU, Jeremy Corbyn and anyone  except herself. The Prime Minister warned wavering MPs the UK could stay in the EUthey rejected her deal again on Tuesday. She told workers in Grimsby: “If MPs reject the deal, nothing is certain. It would be at a moment of crisis. “MPs would immediately be faced with another choice - either we leave the EU with no deal on March  or we delay Brexit and carry on arguing about it.” But despite warning that no-deal would fire consequences she refused to say she would whip her MPs to vote against ither deal fails to pass. Despite weeks of heated negotiations Mrs May did not reveal any substantial changes to the Irish backstop. Speaking directly to EU leaders she urged hem to back the changes she needs to appease the DUP and her own back bench MPs. “My message to them is: now is the moment for us to act,” she said. Instead I’m the face of a second historic defeat she said attempted to pay the blame the deal’s likely failure on Jeremy Corbyn. She said that the Labour leader was “not really interested in finding a solution” - instead accusing him of trying to stop Brexit happening. She added: “I have repeatedly offered him another meeting to follow it up. “In , after multiple requests from my office, he has offered just one hour over the last five weeks when our teams could meet. “And we now know why. “Because despite his promise at the last election to deliver Brexit, he now supports holding a isive second referendum that would take the UK right back to square one. “If we go down that road, we might never leave the EU at all.”

title: international womens day think women
story: NewsopinionOn International Womens Day, think about the women you dont hear fromWe hear from men all the time. We hear from prominent women about good ideas that, very shortly, a man will re-announce like it was hisShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  MAR Newsopinion"Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt is hard to be positive about the prospects for the planets biggest minority when it is represented on the world stage by females best described as not quite up to scratch. When Karen Bradley first says that British soldiers who shot unarmed civilians were following orders, then that she doesnt think that, and finally that she doesnt even believe herself, an observer from out of space could be forgiven for thinking that,she was the best person we could find to juggle with highly-explosive Northern Irish sensitivities, the whole species is heading for the blender.Were you to inform E.T. that Andrea Leadsom thinks British Muslims are the concern of the Foreign Office and Amber Rudd implies darker-skinned people are that way because of marker pens, hed be on his spaceship and getting to a safe distance before you could add that Katie Prices highly-monetised balloon boobs have somehow landed her poundm in debt.Butyou despair of the quality of womanhood in general, you are forgetting something. Because just as they have throughout human history, the women who grab our attention do so because when theres something wrong with them. Rudd is stuck in the s, Leadsom is so th century she lacks only a crinoline and marriageable daughters, and Bradley, plainly, is a malware-infected bot.Theresa May is in the news not because shes spent  years holding her self-immolating party together and dealing with the most dficult political crisis of our letimes, but because men arent happy with how shes doing it. Hillary Clinton is a prominent failure, rather than a ceiling-smashing lawyer who came within a whisker of the White House and was considered such a threat by the men of Russia and Wikileaks that they conspired against her personally with a man who lived in a golden phallus. Oprah Winfrey is fat. Ivanka Trump says stupid things. Angela Merkel isnt much of a looker. Name me ONE GUY about whom you could say all that. But the fact womanhood is a mixed-ability class is not in itself reason to despair. Masculinity has its fair share of fat, stupid, ugly people who do things wrong all the time, and unlike women they rarely apologise for it.Trump expressed no regret for employing criminals, praising Nazis or groping women. Putin murders his critics rather than listen to them. Kim Jong-Un never worries about the size of his cheese-saturated, un-fatshamed bum.We hear from men all the time. We hear from prominent women, too, about apologies, hopes, and good ideas that, very shortly, a man will re-announce like it was his all along. We do not hear from the others.  If human beings were left to procreate naturally, the world would be about % female. Instead its .%.Thats million women. Missing, presumed dead.They are missing because they were aborted for not being boys, killed after birth for the same reason, denied health care, refused education, raped, murdered, brutalised, and left to die from disease and malnutrition. They include Jodie Chesney, stabbed to death on a park bench aged  in an apparently motiveless attack, as well as females who die in childbirth, women killed for the concept of male honour, and teens in cars crashed at speed by men to prove their masculinity. Then there are invisible women who survived long enough to live unnoticed in slums, refugee camps, mud huts, multi-occupancy housing, brothels, massage parlours, prisons and in ordinary streets behind ordinary doors where it is perfectly ordinary for them to suffer and die. Those with better luck get to go to school, except when they have periods and they stay at home. They get to have jobs, so long as they dont ask for too much money and dont mind getting laid off before men. They get to fall in love, so long as they dont complain too much when he mistreats her. And in many countries they get to enjoy all of that for longer and die a little later. The country I live in is better to women than most. Women text to let their mums know they got home without being raped, those who use their legal rights to get better treatment are considered unemployable or unmarriageable, and girls are bullied into sending naked pictures to boys who share them with their friends. Vaginas are stretchy, guys, but not THAT stretchy.Females here are told they dress wrong, think wrong, talk wrong, interrupt wrong, and work wrong. About all a female can be guaranteed to get praised for is dancing in her knickers, a fact which makes me want to stowaway on the first space ship that lingers too long over its crop circle. But dealing with all that for centuries has done something rather brilliant.In much the same way as the women who survive infancy can expect to live longer than men, it has bred a super-race. Women who run countries, corporations, and the international economy as easily as they can run a tap. And millions more who run their homes and lives just as well, but a lot more quietly.For years the only women who succeeded were superior beings, and in their wake have come more who learned by example. Those who tried to have it all, and mostly managed it, have been replaced by women for whom the definition of all has expanded like the Kardashian empire, which turned one instance of sexual exploitation into a billion-dollar female powerhouse.So successful have women been that those born with male genitalia now wish to be reclassied as female. Put aside whatever thoughts you have on the social, physical or cultural acceptability of that - for the first time humans are campaigning NOT to be men.We should be delighted that a woman in Karen Bradleys position is such a remarkable idiot. It at least proves that were used to brilliant women. If we are noticing women who arent up to the standards we expect of frontline troops, it proves women have set a high standard. We are now arguing about a woman presenter on Question Time, a pregnant princess with opinions, pink power tools and period poverty. When I was growing up not a single one of those things existed in the national consciousness or had any hope of doing so.Even better, we are noticing the women who have never been noticed before. The superwomen will have to fix that problem, too, because the guys sure havent got very far. The presence of a few idiots does not mean womanhood is regressing. It means more of us really do enjoy equal opportunities, oies arent holding so many people back, and were judging women on their ability rather than their knickers. Besides, being a moron never stopped a man. Stop the spaceship, I want to get off. Theres work to do.

title: karen bradley left speechless photo
story: NewsKaren Bradley left speechless by photo of boy in coffin shot by the British ArmyThe Northern Ireland Secretary was meeting with families who had lost loved ones at the hands of the British Army and Royal Ulster ConstabularyShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsKaren Bradley has apologised for her comments"Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailKaren Bradley was left speechless after she was shown a photograph of an -year-old boy in his coffin who was shot dead by the British Army. It came during a meeting with families bereaved by security force violence who wanted to express concern about her controversial comments on state killings. Mrs Bradley was handed a number of pictures of the Stephen McConomy who was shot and killed by a plastic bullet close to his home in Derry  Londonderry in . The MP was said to be left speechless at the images him wearing his school unorm two weeks before he was killed and of the boy on a le support machine. The Northern Ireland Secretary reached out to a number of victims groups on a visit to Belfast after she said killings carried out by the police and military during the Troubles were not crimes, rather actions of people fulfilling their duties in a dignied and appropriate way.  Her comments sparked fury among victims and she was forced to backtrack and apologise saying on Thursday: I want to be very clear - I do not believe what I said, that is not my view. The remarks were especially ill-judged coming a week before long-awaited decisions from Northern Ireland prosecutors on whether  soldiers involved in the Bloody Sunday shootings in Derry Londonderry in  will face prosecution. Relatives of those killed in shootings involving the Army in Ballymurphy in west Belfast in  refused to meet the Conservative MP today.   The families, who say they have been requesting a meeting with the minister for some time to no avail, dismissed her apology.John Teggart, whose father Danny was shot  times at Ballymurphy, said Mrs Bradley should resign. We will not meet her, and have one request for Mrs Bradley and that is for her to resign immediately, he said.   But members of the group Relatives for Justice did meet Mrs Bradley so they could tell her how her comments had made them feel. Speaking after the meeting, Frances Meehan, whose brother was shot dead by the British Army in , called for Mrs Bradley to resign. I wanted to meet her because I wanted to look her in the eye to tell her how I felt about her comments in the House of Commons, she said. I also wanted to say to her that on this day, International Womens Day, that she is an insult to women. We know she has apologised but her position is completely and utterly untenable and she needs to resign. Mrs Bradley rowed back on her comments on Thursday as she battled to keep her job. She said: I want to be very clear - I do not believe what I said, that is not my view. I believe that where crimes have happened, no matter who the perpetrator, they should be properly investigated by an independent authority and they should be prosecuted.

title: meghan markle dons mini dress
story: NewsMeghan Markle tells womens  I feel the embryonic kicking of feminismThe Duchess of Sussex and leading female activists are discussing a range of issues affecting women today at Kings College LondonShareCommentsByRussell MyersTony JonesDanya Bazaraa:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video duchess-sussex-discusses-pregnancy-international-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle told leading feminists she loved the phrase I feel the embryonic kicking of feminism as she joined a discussion  marking International Womens Day. The Duchess of Sussex, wearing a pound Azzura black and white mini dress from Reiss, said shed seen a Netflix documentary about feminism where shed heard the expression. She said: I loved that. So boy or girl, whatever it is, we hope that thats the case. Meghan has joined a  of female thought leaders at Kings College London brought together by The Queens Commonwealth Trust - of which she has today become vice-president. Meghan, talking about a range of issues that affect women, has said that from the young age of  she knew she wanted to do something about inequality and sexism. The Duchess has also spoken of the importance of access to education for young girls, arguing it really does solve so many of the world’s problems. She talked about how vital it is to de-stigmatise menstruation in communities, saying its  per cent of the population thats affected by something that can also end up creating the most beautul thing in the world. And Meghan said its important for men to understand they can be feminists as well and be part of the conversation, adding my husband certainly is. The -year-old also revealed during the discussion that she does not look at Twitter, saying: I don’t look at it. Sorry no. For me that is my personal preference. Those joining the Duchess for the chat include Annie Lennox and former prime minister of Australia Julia Gillard.  Meghan has been described by the s host as a royal not afraid to embrace full-on feminism. Asked how her pregnancy was going, she said: Very well. Its funny, Id actually been joking these past few weeks Id seen this documentary on Netflix about feminism and one of the things they said during pregnancy was I feel the embryonic kicking of feminism. I loved that. So boy or girl, whatever it is, we hope that thats the case.   The group today are talking about the positive opportunities that come when women are given wider access and equal opportunities. Annie Lennox is founder of The Circle, an organisation supporting and empowering womens lives around the world, while Ms Gillard is chairwoman of the Global Institute for Womens Leadership at Kings College London, which is hosting the event. Other members of the  include Adwoa Aboah, who set up the open social discussion  Gurls Talk and Chrisann Jarrett, founder of the equal access to higher education campaign Let Us Learn. Also on the  is Angeline Murimirwa, executive director of the Campaign for Female Education in Africa and co-founder of Cama, a pan-African network of young female leaders. The  is chaired by Anne McElvoy, senior editor of The Economist and columnist with the Evening Standard.   Asked about her own personal journey, Meghan said: “At the age of  I had seen a commercial at the time that I thought to be very sexist. Truth be told, at , I didnt even know what sexism meant. I just knew that something struck me internally that was telling me it was wrong, and I knew that it was wrong. She said she used that as her moral compass, adding: It really set up the trajectory for me to say,there was a wrong,there is a lack of justice, and there is an inequality, then someone needs to do something. And why not me  Once I became old enough to travel, specically to developing countries and see what was happening abroad, I think for me what really resonated was the lack of education for girls, and how that has a ripple effect on so many things, she said today. Meghan added: It really does solve so many of the world’s problems when a girl has access to education. You look at it and you can say, here are the vulnerabilities and the challenges that come about when they don’t have access to education, she continued. Early childhood marriage, susceptibility to trafficking, modern slavery, all of that. But equally look at all the positives that come out of it when you do have access to education for young girls. How it affects the economic development, the GDP. Billions of dollars on the table are lost by girls being pulled out of education.   Meghan spoke about work in India she did a few years ago with a grassroots organisation trying to de-stigmatise menstruation. She said: Giving them access to be able to get these products, but in the same construct having these women mobilised to set up microfinance to sell these pads and other things that are needed to other women in the community. So again it feels like its one issue but it ends up solving so many. Because when you see how many girls are hindered and taken out of school simply because theyre ashamed about going through that transition in le, or because no-one wants to talk to them about it because they dont have what they need and theyre using old rags - literally. Which of course is propelling disease and so many other symptoms that come from this. At the end of the day, we are doing our part just to normalise the conversation. Thats the first step. Because again this is  per cent of the population thats affected by something that can also end up creating the most beautul thing in the world. So its a strange one that its ended up becoming so stigmatised. Remember its also in our own communities that its happening, and the only way we sht that is by talking about it which is why the work you do with Gurls Talk is so important.  Meghan has today become vice-president of the Queens Commonwealth Trust, the organisation has announced. The Duchess has joined her husband Harry, who is president, at the body, while the Queen is its patron. In this new role, the Duchess will highlight the trusts partnerships with young people across the Commonwealth, and in particular its work supporting women and girls, the trust said in a statement. The announcement was made a few hours before the discussion , organised by the Trust, of leading feminists and national figures to mark International Womens Day. Nicola Brentnall, the Trusts chief executive, said: We are particularly delighted that the first opportunity of formally working together with Her Royal Highness comes on International Womens Day. This squares perfectly with our focus on amplying the work and contribution of those furthest away from power. Women across the Commonwealth and the globe often face the biggest impediments to success. So we are delighted to have our vice-presidents support in helping others to overcome those obstacles.  Today Meghan told the  she felt privileged to have her role. She said: And I think, you know, looking at my role, and Im very very privileged to have now with the QCT, just expands that  to be able to go to  Commonwealth countries and do this level of work all across the globe because again, it is about global feminism, it is about a parity and equality for all of us. It started at , but still feels like its just beginning. Meghan has made womens empowerment a key part of her campaigning work and during her recent tour of Morocco with the Duke told a group of female executives and entrepreneurs: Women have to challenge everywhere in the world.

title: mum wins landmark case over
story: NewsMum wins landmark case over baffling road sign that made council £k a weekEmma Bartholomews mum was fined at a notoriously baffling no left turn sign that has made a council nearly £millionShareByTalia Shadwell:,  MAR NewsReporter Emma Bartholomew took on Hackney Council over her mums fine and won"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum-of-three has won a landmark case against a council over a fine at a baffling no left turn sign that has made the authority over poundmillion. And Emma Bartholomews triumph could open the floodgates to similar cases over inadequate road sign claims at other spots bringing in cash for councils. When Emmas mum was fined by Hackney Council at the confusing bend, she decided to take on the East London local authority.The Hackney Gazette journalist noted it had made more than pound million in the nine months since the cameras had been installed.  She decided to help her mum appeal the ticket after her mum was stung with a fine while she was on her way to perform an act of generosity. Emmas mum had been dropping off clothing donations to St Josephs Hospice in Mare St for its charity jumble sale when she was snapped, she said. Rather than have her mum pay the pound fine, Emma decided it was time to do something about the notorious fine spot. She said her mum had no idea about the camera. An independent adjudicator ultimately agreed with the mother-daugter duo that the signs at the turn from Mare St into Richmond Rd were inadequate.  But Emmas mum risked being slapped with an even bigger fine by taking the council on after it initially rejected their request to overturn the fine. By appealing the pound discount charge, Emmas mum faced it growing to poundshe lost the case. But the tribunal agreed with the pair and overturned Emmas mums fine. Sean Stanton-Dunne of London Tribunals told the Gazette he had come across the case at least five times. He said each time “sent a clear message” to the council the signs in Mare Street were “inadequate.”Allowing the appeal, Mr Stanton-Dunne said: “The no left turn sign is positioned beyond the traffic lights so that it may not be clearly seen before the lights.   The lights are in front of the sign and so risk causing an obstructed view from car level in the left hand lane. “There is an advance warning sign further back from the lights but this is tilted at an angle so that it does not directly face the approaching motorist.” However he does not have the power to force changes. The signs are supposed to warn vehicles they can can no longer turn left into Richmond Road between am and am, and pm and pm, from Monday to Saturday. The change was made last June due to the street outside London Fields Primary School being made a school street in an effort to reduce air pollution. But the stretch has subsequently become a cash cow the local council.   Figures revealed by the Gazette showed Hackney Council was raking in pound, a day from the spot, with almost , people hit by penalty charge noticessince its installation. Just  people, or  per cent of all those issued with a PCN, appealed to the independent adjudicator, where a third won. Just , of the the , notices motorists have tried to appeal in the last nine months have been cancelled. But the council reportedly did not agree with the ruling, with a spokesman telling the Gazette they believe the Department of Transport-approved signs go over and above the requirements for a restriction of this type. A spokesperson added: “Nonetheless we always remain open to making further improvements, and will be inviting an adjudicator to visit Richmond Road so that we can discuss any concerns they may have, and agree how to address them for the benefit of motorists.” But the reporter who took on the council doesnt think her battle ends here. She has pointed out the local authority says the sign adheres to DoT guidelines. She told the Mirror she has no answers yet on whether they will change the signs to make it less confusing. Obviously I think they should, but there doesnt seem to be any authority who can make them do that. Theyve changed the signs once already after some people got hit with more than  tickets when it was first introduced. They obviously havent yet done enough to make the sign visible enough - and the adjudicator agreed with me. Emma pointed outthe scheme is supposed to be for the benefit of the local school:I do wonder why its still in force on a Saturday from am to am and pm to pm, when the school is closed. It does seem to indicate that theyre happy with the situation as it is and the phenomenal amount of money the sign is racking up.

story: AdvertorialHow British firms could be losing millions by getting sucked into the tech raceYorkshire Banks Group Business Banking Director gives his verdict on the biggest technology questions for small businesses in ShareByDave Masters:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Advertorial"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTechnology is vital for all businesses up and down the country. It can revolutionise how a company works in so many areas, from more efficient front line production to improved data analysis. But with technological advances moving at a faster rate than human skills, it is vital for small and medium sized businesses to keep up. So to help, Yorkshire Bank’s Group Business Banking Director, Gavin Opperman, is here to answer your questions... Q How can small businesses reduce costs associated with new technology  A Every small business needs technology to support them to make their business more efficient. Technology is moving faster than human skills are, which is why it is necessary for small businesses to weigh up exactly what piece of technology they want to own, its longevity and whether its development can be outsourced. Q Is understanding the latest technology essential for all small businesses  A Most small businesses will need to adopt some level of technology to make their business run efficiently. However,small businesses get caught up in the technology race too much they can move away from their core business. Remember to find a balance between what is needed and how to make the businessoptimally. Q What technology should small businesses be looking out for  A Every small business is dferent. There’s a number of exhibitions that they can attend to see what technology is most suited to them. Small businesses should look for options that will give them long-term sustainability at an economical rate and ultimately make their business more efficient. Q Many small businesses are struggling with the complexity of new technology – how can they simply the concept  A At Yorkshire Bank, we strive to bring industry experts and like-minded people together. Many of the sectors or businesses are prepared to share their knowledge to others in the industry. It is about finding the right technology to fit your business, and one that is suitable over a long period. Q How can small businesses keep up to date with the latest products and services available  A When it comes to technology, Yorkshire Bank provides a relationship model. We as bankers aren’t there as technology experts, but what we can do is share best practice. We can introduce small businesses to experts in our portfolio who can advise on the latest products and services available. Q Many small businesses are hindered by time and internal resources – how can they still embrace new technology  A The biggest challenge Yorkshire Bank has identied with small businesses is the skills shortage, which puts pressure on internal resources. A lot of universities are developing skills in technology, but it’s how small businesses can retain the talent within that. The aim would be to keep the intellectual property within  the region, so small businesses can embrace new technology without added time or training.Find out more about a business bank that works for you at YBonline business

story: NewsTeens bragged they were on the run for murder after beating angler to deathScott Wilkinson suffered fatal brain injuries after being attacked by two teenagers and their cousins in SurreyShareByBen CusackTfany Lo:,  MAR NewsScott Wilkinson, , was killed by three members of the same family during a summer fishing trip in  "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA group of teens bragged to their friends that they were on the run for murder after beating a fisherman to death in Surrey. Scott Wilkinson, , was battered to death with a plank of wood by brothers Lenny and Shane Crawt, aged  and  at the time, and their then -year-old cousin Charlie Smith. The Crawt brothers, now  and , were found guilty of murder and Smith, , was found guilty of manslaughter at Guildford Crown Court on March . The -year-old was murdered during a nighttime fishing expedition on Donkey Island, near his home in Walton-on-Thames, Surrey, in July, .   He suffered fatal brain injuries when the three young men brutally assaulted him with a piece of wood. The jury heard how the Crawt brothers and their cousin Smith had been camping on the island. They fled to nearby Grovelands Park after the incident and met a gang of youths they knew. According to Surrey Police, one of the three said: I wouldnt say anythingI was you because we killed someone tonight. Smith told an old school friend that he was on the run for murder.   Detective Inspector Paddy Mayers, who led the investigation, said: This was a vicious and senseless attack on Scott Wilkinson who after the attack was left alone to die. His injuries were so serious that they were not survivable. Shane Crawt, Lenny Crawt and Charlie Smith thought they had got away with it and even boasted about what they had done. They then denied their involvement before blaming each other, putting Scotts family through a distressing trial where they had to listen to graphic detail to what Scott had gone through.   DI Mayers said the trio had never shown any remorse for what they have done. After the verdict, Scotts family shared a heart-wrenching tribute. They said: We have such fond memories of Scott which include him misbehaving with his brother Shaun when they were children much to the consternation of his mother Janet and humorous delight of his father David. Fishing was a family hobby which brought us all together. It created shared experiences during long summer holidays, adventurous trips to Ireland with long drawn out tales of the one that got away. The energy and enthusiasm which Scott directed towards fishing was reflective of his character towards people. He offered friendship, kindness and closeness to those that wanted or needed it. He enriched the lives of the people who knew him. Shane Crawt, from Purley, Lenny, from West Molesey, and Charlie Smith, of no fixed abode will be sentenced at the same court at a later date.

story: NewsInside remains of stunning th century house where gold is buriedRockwell house in Milledgeville, Georgia, was built for Colonel Samuel Rockwell in  and he is said to have suffered a heart attack at finding out the cost of the cast iron fenceShareCommentsByMark McConville:,  MAR NewsRockwell House "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRemains of a th century house where gold is rumoured to be buried have been revealed in stunning images. The original owner is said to have had a heart attack after learning his fence cost more than the house, according to urban explorer known as Abandoned Southeast who took the photos. The house, which was a labour of love, features a grand entrance with steps leading to an intricate porch and pillars, and the cast iron fence said to have provoked the heart attack.   Other incredible images show the spacious interior with most of the rooms cleared out, while ornate woodwork remains above the doors and fireplace with two lonely seats being all thats left. This magnicent home was built for Colonel Samuel Rockwell in  in Milledgeville, Georgia, said Abandoned Southeast. The Rockwell House was built by architect Joseph Lane Sr, who Rockwell brought with him from Maine. Lane also designed buildings at nearby Oglethorpe University. He added: A cast iron fence in front of the extensive lawn is reported to have cost , when it was new while the house only cost ,.   The story is told that when Col Rockwell learned of the cost of the fence, he had a heart attack. There are no markings on the fence as to where it came from. One source said the fence came from London, England. Many historians believe the fence to have been cast in Milledgeville. It has been attributed to the Dugal Fern and Brothers Foundry. He continued: There are a number of stories and rumours about the Rockwell House including a rumor of gold buried in the vicinity of the house.  Col Rockwell was the seventh generation of Rockwells in America. He was born in  in Albany, New York. Rockwell moved from Maine to Georgia in . He was a slave holder and a member of the Georgia Militia. Prior to his law practice in Milledgeville, he served as an attorney in Savannah. Rockwell House was occupied by Col Rockwell and his family for only a very short period due to his death in . It is not knownthe house was left vacant, but eventually the property was owned by Hershel V Johnson.  Strangest things in UK museums - and why you might not be able to see them for longIn , Johnson became Governor and used the residence as his summer home. In the following years, Rockwell House was home to numerous merchants and farmers. Mr Marshall Bland purchased the house in  and lived there a decade. The house was sold by Mr Bland to his cousin, Oscar Ennis, who occupied the home with his family until .   The house was sold to Dr Robert Watson in . Dr Watson began work to restore the home until tragedy struck. In August , while removing paint with a blow torch, workers set fire to an upstairs portion of the house. The house was stripped of a lot of its original features after this fire. A renovation has been underway since  to restore the Rockwell House. This year it was purchased by Ross Sheppard, a realtor in Atlanta who specialises in historic preservation.

title: look angel points secret codes
story: NewsLook where the angel points: Secret codes, the Vatican and a missing schoolgirlEmanuela Orlandi, , disappeared  years ago and now the Vatican is considering opening an unmarked tomb to seeher body is insideShareByMatt Roper:,  MAR NewsEmanuela vanished in  "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt’s a tale of murder, secret codes and conspiracy - and even Opus Dei - that could have come straight from the pages of a Dan Brown novel. The fate of Emanuela Orlandi, a -year-old girl who disappeared without a trace from the Vatican on the way to a flute lesson in , has gripped Italians for the last three decades. But now the mystery could finally unravel - with a coded message which appears to indicate where the teenager’s body was secretly buried. “Look where the angel points,” reads the message in an anonymous letter sent to her family. The angel is a centuries-old stone statue on top of an unmarked tomb within the the Teutonic Cemetery, which lies within the Vatican walls.   And unlike other many similar statues in the tiny city state, the angel’s hand is pointing downwards - towards whatever is buried underneath. The cemetery is not accessible to the general public and no-one knows who was once buried there.Yet the tomb is mysteriously tended every day, with a lit red votive candle that is never allowed to go out, and always fresh flowers in a vase. The only thing engraved on it is a marble scroll the angel holds, which reads Requiescat in Pace - or Rest in Peace. The Orlandi family now wants the Pope to grant permission to exhume whoever or whatever lies inside the tomb, which is reported to have been opened “at least once” - and resealed - within the last few decades.   A Vatican spokesman this week said in a statement that the Holy See is “studying” the matter and will soon decide whether to honour the request. If Emanuela is found to have been murdered and buried inside the Vatican it could engulf the Catholic church in its biggest scandal to date. And it will give oxygen to one of the most sensational theories about her disappearance - that the schoolgirl was kidnapped by high-ranking clerics who kept her as a sex slave before killing her. Pierto Orlandi, Emanuela’s brother, said he believes the Vatican’s highest powers know much more about his sister’s disappearance than they have so far let on. “I wish so much that this story was a hoax. I really wish Emanuela was not here,” he told a local newspaper. While this is the most precise indication yet of where she might be buried, the claim that she was snatched by a Vatican paedophile ring has been made before - by people close to the Churchs very centre of power.  The Vaticans chief exorcist Father Gabriele Amorth, a great confidant of retired Pope Emeritus Benedict XVI, said in  that Emanuela was snatched from the streets of central Rome in the summer of  and forced to take part in sex parties.Fr Amorth, who died in , said: This was a crime with a sexual motive. Parties were organised, with a Vatican gendarme acting as the recruiter of the girls. The network involved diplomatic personnel from a foreign embassy to the Holy See. I believe Emanuela ended up a victim of this circle.”In , Monsignor Simeone Duca, an archivist with the Vatican, backed up the exorcist’s claims.He cited “credible information” that “certain factions” inside the Vatican’s diplomatic corps were involved in procuring young adolescent girls for sexual slavery. He, too, said he believed that the teenager was abducted for that purpose and later murdered. It is not the only theory that has emerged about what happened to Emanuela in what is still one of Italy’s most enduring mysteries.  They include the early claim that Turkish militants tied to the assassination attempt against Pope John Paul II had taken the schoolgirl to secure the release of Mehmet Ali Agca, who tried to shoot the pope in . Then, in , the mistress of a gangster named Enrico De Pedis told authorities that he organised Emanuelas kidnapping at the behest of the controversial American archbishop, Paul C. Marcinkus, the former president of the Vatican Bank, who died in . Some have suggested that Emanuelas father Ercole, a Vatican clerk, had evidence of wrongdoing committed by Marcinkus, and that he asked De Pedis to kidnap the girl to keep the clerk quiet. A traffic warden who had seen Emanuela speaking to a man in a green BMW the night she disappeared worked to produce a sketch of the man, who looked very similar to De Pedis. And in , Italian journalist Emiliano Fittipaldi published a document that had been stolen from the Vatican. It appears to show that the church knew where the teen was and had been paying her expenses for years, including room and board and gynaecological examinations.  The Vatican called the document  and ridiculous. What is without doubt, though, are the very strange circumstances which surrounded her sudden vanishing on June , . The teenager, who had just finished her second year of high school, left the left the familys apartment in Vatican City and travelled to a flute lesson in Rome. On the way to the flute lesson, the man in the green BMW stopped her on the street and offered her money to sell Avon cosmetics, which she refused. Troubled, she called her sister to tell her about the incident. Once she arrived at the lesson, she was distracted and asked to leave early, around .pm. Emanuela was last seen in front of SantApollinare, a church in Rome belonging to the ultra-secretive Catholic organisation Opus Dei that played a mayor role in The Da Vinci Code novel. In the days after her disappearance the Orlandi family started receiving anonymous calls with tips about their daughters whereabouts, none of them leading anywhere.  Pope John Paul II waded into the case on July , , when he made a public appeal for her safeafter a public prayer, saying I am close to the Orlandi family. Two days after the pope’s address, someone called both the Orlandi family and the Vatican, saying that a group had taken the teen to secure the release of Mehmet Ali Agca. The caller, who was American, backed up his claims by leading agents to a photocopy of Emanuelas registration card for her music school, and sending a letter containing photo copies of the sheet music she was studying at the time. But he stopped communicating after October  and was never heard from again. A number of attempts have also been made recently to locate Emanuela’s remains, with the first linked to the secretive Opus Dei church. The only person ever investigated over the disappearance was Monsignor Piero Vergari, the former rector of the Sant’Apollinare church where she went missing. He was a friend of gangster Enrico De Pedis, and after he died he petitioned to let his body be buried at the Basilica of SantApollinare, a place usually reserved for senior clerics, not criminals.  In , De Pediss grave was exhumed to see whether Emanuelas remains might be hidden inside with his, but although, bizarrely, there were lots of human bones around his tomb, nothing matched the missing teen. And last November, workers renovating an annex of the Vaticans embassy to Italy in Rome discovered bones underneath the flooring, sparking immediate questions they may be connected to the teenager’s disappearance. Sometime after Emanuela’s disappearance, Monsignor Vergari is reported to have worked at the embassy. But the bones turned out to be around  years old. This week’s new lead could yet be another blind alley, or could maybe finally solve the mystery that has obsessed Italy, and haunted the Orlandi family, for over three decades. Emanuela’s brother Pierto knows there is still a long way to go to find the truth, especially as it could take weeks, months or even years, for the Vatican to respond to his family’s request to open the tomb. And with each day that goes by, he is more convinced that the Church knows much more about what happened to his lost sister than they had ever been willing to admit. He said: “Weve been asking for collaboration from the Vatican for  years. “Collaboration that has never been. This time we are asking again. Even collaboration that is discreet, just to understand. Just to remove this doubt.”

story: NewsMum blasted for leaving five-year-old home alone to cook - and wanting sympathyThe heavily pregnant mum popped out to get a lunch she was cravingShareCommentsByZahra MulroySocial Audience Editor:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsThe little lad was left to fend for himself "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNo one would argue that having young kids is full on.That hateful mummy brain phrase  It exists because parents are often run ragged just trying to keep everything afloat.But does that justy leaving a five-year-old home alone, evenfor an hour  Evenyou believe he can fend for himself  One mum seems to think so, and its caused a huge backlash.The mum, who is also  weeks pregnant turned to Facebook for sympathy, writing in a group: Its a pain being pregnant and having to get my son ready and in the car, so I usually leave him home behind my fianceacutes back .  Well today I got caught. Since Im pregnant I was craving this specic place in the mall. My sons lunch was in the oven and figured by the time it was ready I would be home. My son is potty trained and just plays games on his iPad watches TV. Half an hour after popping out to satisfy her lunch craving, the mum received furious text messages from her fianceacute, who had come back to find his son completely home alone. As for her reaction, she added: I feel degraded and belittled over nothing. A  year-old is perfectly capable of fending for himself for an hour.   Im honestly about to pack my bags and never let my son see his father again...Id rather be a single mother than be spoken to this way. Of course, asking for no judgement did nothing to stop a flood of it coming her way. I mean I might argue a kid can handle themselves for a bit, but a whole hour, with the oven running, no food ready, while she is out at a mall  read one of the more generous responses. She knowingly left her young five-year-old kid at home alone unsupervised with the oven on. Thats insanity, fumed another - and again, thats one of the kinder response. Having asked Reddit how theyd feel in her shoes about her fianceacute, one person added savagely: Its the grim realisation that he fathered a child with a moronic drama queen setting in.

title: mums horrible name baby two
story: NewsMums horrible name for baby with two unfortunate meanings ides parentsThe mum-to-be was worried that it wouldnt age wellShareCommentsByZahra MulroySocial Audience Editor:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsOne mum-to-be s choice has come under fire "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAs much as you may love your choice of baby name at the time, theres always a danger it may not age well. Theres also a chance that it will come back into fashion, but this isnt always a guarantee.After all, Nigel has sadly been languishing on the endangered list for quite some time now.So you cant blame one mum-to-be for testing the waters with a baby name she loves. While some people agreed with her and thought it was lovely, others described it as horrible.  Explaining a little bit about her background on Reddit , she wrote: My fianceacute and I are international intercultural -hes Indonesian and Dutch, and Im Dutch and American, which means that whatever names we choose need to sound good in each of our languages.Many of the traditional English names I love are no-goes for this reason, because they sound beautul in one language and awful in another. With this in mind, she and her partner have settled on Vesper. But she has her doubts about the name too...  The mum-to-be then adds: First, its pretty modernso Im worried it might age poorly. Another factor to consider is that my partners last name begins with a V. If she gets only his name, shell be Vesper Vernon. Is this too much  If she takes both our names, shed be Vesper Walker Vernon. The feedback came in thick and fast. “Too close to vespa meaning wasp in Italian,” one woman responded.  In German, colloquially, Vesper means a late afternoon snack or dinner. I realise, you can’t mind every translation in every language, but since German is pretty close to Dutch, is there maybe a similar meaning in Dutch  another pointed out. AHAHAHAHAHA OH MY GOD NO THIS IS HORRIBLE, added one sensitive soul. Happily, the mum-to-be has a contingency plan, and reveals she also likes the names Hannah, Philippa , and Caroline. Maybe go with one of those

title: pregnant mum unborn baby girl
story: NewsPregnant mum and unborn baby girl die suddenly together days before due dateJanay Johnstone, from Auckland, New Zealand, who was due to give birth this month, had posted exciting and loving Facebook posts before she died unexpectedly aged ShareCommentsBySophie Evans:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsJanay Johnstone died suddenly this week, along with her precious unborn child "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA pregnant mum and her unborn baby daughter have died suddenly together in a double tragedy just days before her due date.Talented photographer Janay Johnstone, , who was nine months pregnant with her little girl, passed away unexpectedly earlier this week.Her precious unborn baby could sadly not be saved. Janay, whose cause of death is currently unclear, and her childhood sweetheart Mark had waited a long time for their miracle second child.The couple, who also have a toddler son Tiare, had been accepted for IVF when they found out they were expecting again, loved ones say.Their baby daughter was due to be born this month. Janay, from Auckland, New Zealand, had been seemingly healthy before her death, with no signs that anything was wrong during her pregnancy.   A kind-hearted woman, she had volunteered for Heartfelt, a selfless group of professional photographers who capture photos of families in hospital.She would take pictures for parents whose babies were very sick, or had died, so they could have valuable keepsakes, the New Zealand Herald reports.Her family told the newspaper that her death this week was sudden. They said the expectant mother was laid back and independent, with her le revolving around aircraft technician Mark and three-year-old Tiare. It was a very long process to conceive Tiare and they had been accepted for IVF when Janay got pregnant with baby number two, her grieving sister-in-law, Lana Mitchell, told the Herald. It was a miracle. Janay, who had trained as a graphic artist, had been with Mark for  years - and married for seven - after they met in a nightclub as teenagers.She ran her own business, Tee-Jay Photography . On the firms Facebook page, she describes herself as the face behind the camera and proud mum to little Tiare, with another on the way. She says: My passion for newborn photography started with my son, the moment I watched my son being photographed as a newborn, I thought would be the best job in the world! Working with the most precious little miracles, what more is there to love. As a mum I know how fast our babys grow, especially in their first year . My sons newborn baby portraits are priceless to me and I have them proudly displayed on my walls - I would love the opportunity to do this for you too. She posted what would be her final message on the page on Tuesday. She excitedly wrote: Some big news for our growing family, we are moving to the beautul Central Otago in May! Just days earlier, she had shared a picture of herself and Mark on her own Facebook page, saying: Always having a laugh with this guy x. Ollie Dale, president of the NZ Institute of Professional Photography, said Janay was vibrant and a popular member of the photographic community. He said of her death: As far as I know she had no health issues, it was completely unexpected and she was a vibrant and bubbly person. He has now set up a Givealittle fundraising page in the mums memory, where people can donate to help her husband and little boy.A post on the page reads: It is with deep regret that we mourn the passing of Janay Johnstone. A we, a mother, a photographer Janay was a wonderful mum to her beautul boy and so excited to meet her wee girl due this month. She was bubbly and vivacious with a heart of gold. Janay was an incredibly talented photographer, and an absolute baby whisperer. She will be greatly missed. Among her other endeavours, Janay was a Heartfelt photographer, giving herself and her precious time for other families who suffered their own tragic losses. Janay and her unborn baby girl sadly passed away together. It adds: If you would like to donate to help Janays husband Mark and Janays family, please do so here. All funds go directly to Mark. So far, more than ,has been raised. Janay and her baby daughter are now resting at home, according to local media. They will be laid to rest by loved ones tomorrow.
