title: student who fell asleep wearing
story: NewsStudent who fell asleep wearing ear buds wakes up DEAF in one earThe student, from Taiwan, who left his ear buds in as he slept received treatment just in time to prevent permanent ear damageShareCommentsByTalia Shadwell:,  MAR NewsDo relax while listening to music - but best not to fall asleep with earbuds in, experts warn "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA student who fell asleep with his ear buds in woke up DEAF in one ear. Doctors revealed the cautionary tale to make those of us who have a habit of falling asleep listening to music think twice. They sayone of the ear buds had not fallen out while the second-year university student was sleeping, he might have lost his hearing in both ears. The student gradually got his hearing back and narrowly avoided permanent hearing damage after receiving treatment at hospital in Taiwan. The man, who has not been identied, was reportedly treated at Asia University Hospital in Taichung City, where medics used the case to warn people to avoid falling asleep with ear buds in.Ear, nose and throat specialist Dr Tian Huiji, director of otorhinolaryngology, told OMG Taiwan that while people might listen to loud music during the day without experiencing sudden deafness, it is dangerous to do the same at night. The doctor explained that when sleeping the bodys blood circulation slows down. That leaves the highly-sensitive sensory hair cells in our ears responsible for detecting sound-waves less able to protect our hearing from loud sounds.That can result in sudden deafness. Ear buds are particularly risky culprits because, unlike headphones, they restrict any sound from escaping, Mail Online reports.Medical experts have been warning for years that young peoples use of ear buds to blast loud music is affecting their hearing in the long term. The NHS has also warned of the dangers of turning up the volume at full blast, saying it can cause long-term hearing damage. The World Health Organisationestimates  shymillion of people are severely disabled by hearing loss.One expert recently told the Mirror as our environment is becoming increasingly noisier , our use of headphones to drown out that background cacophony is a key problem.It can be tempting to blast your favourite song at full volume to cover up the noise of your rush hour morning commute. But it could be doing you long-term damage. The NHS warns against listening to music through earphones and headphones too loudly.It says the devices are among the biggest dangers to your hearing.Helpful official NHS tips include:Using noise-cancelling headphones rather than turning up the volume to cover up outside noise. Dont listen to music at more than  per cent of the maximum volume. Checkyour device has automatic volume-limiting settings. Turn up the volume just high enough so you can hear music comfortably, but no louder. Dont use earphones or headphones for more than an hour at a time. Take a break from listening through them for at least five minutes every hour.  The numbers affected by hearing loss globally are thought likely to grow. Our world is becoming ever-noisier with the growl of traffic and the modern demand to be constantly wired in to technology, and both are thought to be key factors in long-term damage. In recent weeks the WHO predicted an shyadditional one billion people globally, or half of all - year olds, were at risk of hearing damage.And last year a Dutch study found listening to loud music through headphones is damaging youngsters hearing - and could have lelong consequences.They said it was the first study ever to conclusively link portable music devices and noise-induced hearing loss in the younger age group. The scientists, who studied more than , children aged nine to -years-old over three years, found one in seven of the youngsters had suffered some kind of hearing loss.

title: council set to allow coffee shops and nurseries to move into successful dundee technology park
story: The council has unveiled plans to boost Technology Park by allowing a wider range of businesses to use the site.And development chiefs have hailed the “success” of the park, which is more than three-quarters full.Council chiefs hope to welcome in a wider range of businesses in the Tech Park – so long as they compliment its existing offering.The park already hosts an Oranges and Lemons nursery, which is popular with parents who work on the estate – and businesses such as that, or an on-site coffee shop, are likely to be welcomed.However, the council has warned that businesses that any such bids will have to “serve employees based in the Technology Park rather than draw further traffic into this employment area”.Gregor Hamilton, head of planning and economic development, will make a pitch to councillors next week to lt planning restrictions currently in place.Together with city development boss Robin Presswood, Mr Hamilton is hatching plans to take back derelict buildings from owners and work with business chiefs to promote the Tech Park anew.He will tell members on Monday current rules permitting only offices and manufacturing facilities “narrowly restrict” the potential role it has to play in Dundee’s economic growth.Mr Hamilton will say: “It is clear the Dundee Technology Park has been a success and signicantly contributes to key employment sectors within Dundee.“Through improved joint working with key stakeholders, the park can be positively promoted with the support of Dundee City Council to build up the unique business park setting.”A number of key buildings, including a graffiti-covered block that looks on to Riverside Avenue, remain vacant and are falling into disrepair.Two of the park’s empty units hold almost % of the total empty space available at the park.One proposal from Mr Hamilton is that the council could apply for a compulsory purchase or sale order to seize unsightly buildingsowners refuse to take action.West End Labour councillor Richard McCready said he was glad to see action being taken.“We need to make sure Tech Park is fit for the st Century and promote jobs by working together with owners, Scottish Enterprise and anyone with Dundee’s best interests at heart.“The park has to play as much of a role as it can and it can do better than it has been. I hope this report is not a one-off, and we keep monitoring it to make sure it remains an important source of jobs.”Alison Henderson, CEO of Dundee and Angus Chamber of Commerce, said: “Tech Park is a gateway to the city for those coming in from Perth or who come along Riverside – as a first impression it can be mixed.”

title: dundee drink driver 22 told cops she didnt have her keys while hiding them in her underwear
story: A banned motorist who denied drink-driving despite having the car keys in her pants has avoided a jail term.Caitlin McDonald, , was also found with cocaine while out in the city centre last month.Dundee Sherf Court heard she tried to flee from police before lying to them, telling officers she didn’t have the keys to her car.Police conducted a search after tracking her down and finding them in her underwear. The offence came almost a year after McDonald was disqualied from driving for  months.Police became aware of security guard McDonald driving in the city centre in the early hours of February .After spotting the officers, McDonald was seen to reverse her car “at speed” into a car park on St Andrews Street.Depute fiscal Lora Apostolova said: “Officers saw her abandon the car and run off into the car park.“Later that same night, the same police officers traced her. She was asked to release the keys and she said she did not have them.”The keys were later recovered from McDonald while she was at police headquarters on West Bell Street.McDonald, of Wolseley Street, pleaded guilty to driving while disqualied, testing  mics of alcohol in ml of breath, exceeding the limit of  mics, attempting to pervert the course of justice and possessing a Class A drug, namely cocaine.Sherf Lorna Drummond said: “It seems to me quite obvious custody would be warranted.“You are obviously a danger to the public and yourself when you are driving.”Instead of jail, McDonald was ordered to carry out  hours unpaid work, was placed on a restriction of liberty order for  weeks, keeping her indoors between pm-am, and given  months’ supervision.She was also disqualied from driving for  months.

title: dundee gaffer mcintyre delighted at signing winger josh todd
story: Dundee manager Jim McIntyre is “delighted” to have secured the pre-contract signing of winger Josh Todd.The -year-old has impressed at Queen of the South over the past year and the Dens Park boss says he’s been a fan of the former St Mirren man for a while.The Tele revealed back in January the Dark Blues were making a move for the Englishman to bring him in at the end of his contract after he shone for the Doonhamers in their - Scottish Cup draw at Dens Park.Todd set up the opening goal for Stephen Dobbie and was a constant menace to the home defence – something Jim is hoping to see from the midfielder in his side next season.He said: “Josh Todd is a player I have liked for a while.“I went to watch him a couple of times before we played them and he did exceptionally well and then did really well in the game here at Dens.“I’m delighted we managed to do that so I’m looking forward to seeing him in the summer.“He’s not a traditional winger that’ll hit the byline but he makes great runs beyond the strikers and he’s got a goal in him.“He’s an athlete, he can get up and down the pitch, has really good conditioning and knows where the goal is.“He’s also quick. You can’t have enough players with pace.“He’s played No  as well and he fits the bill in terms of the type of player we want to bring to the club.”Despite the club’s immediate future unclear as they battle relegation from the Premiership, that’s not stopped Jim putting preparations in place.In the immediate future, however, is Hearts on Saturday at Dens Park.Jim was at Firhill on Monday night to watch the Jambos draw - with Partick in the Scottish Cup and is hopeful his side can repeat their - success at Tynecastle last month.He added: “We had a really good result against them last time.“They’ve had a wee sticky period with injuries but we know we’ll have to defend better than we have because we will be tested.“I always feel we have a chance of winning games, especiallywe can get our strikers fit and, with the wide players we have, I feel we are always going to create.”

title: dundee owners make fresh bid to supporters society to increase shares
story: Dundee FC’s owners have made a fresh bid to boost their control in the club to over %.The Tele revealed in January that Football Partners Scotland , the majority shareholder owned by Tim Keyes, had made a move to buy the ‘A’ Ordinary shares owned by the Dundee Football Club Supporters Society.With those came rights of veto regarding a range of issues including a stadium share or potential merger with another club.That was knocked back by the Society and now Dundee finance director David Gray has written to them in an attempt to buy their Ordinary shares to bring FPS’ holding to .%.This would allow them to claim Group Tax Relief to offset losses made by the club. A deadline of March  has been made by the club for the Society to decide on two proposals put forward by Dundee FC.The first would see FPS buy the Ordinary shares for £,, the club’s preferred option. These shares have a nominal value, at  pence per share, of £,.The second is for DFCSS to “agree to support resolutions which increase the club’s share capital and then allot shares specically to FPS”.Currently there is no provision in the Society’s rules to sell shares and an extraordinary general meeting would be needed to change that, and with it a vote by its members.The Financial Conduct Authority would also need to be contacted, a process which could take months.DFCSS already had a board meeting scheduled for next Tuesday and will discuss the proposals and their response as a board as well as with their members, despite the sharp time constraint.In a statement, the club added: “At a time when our primary focus is on retaining our Premiership status, we would prefer not to have to undertake an unnecessary time consuming and expensive full share issue and we hope that the Society will support us in agreeing to one of the suggested options.”

title: embrace title race pressure urges dundee uniteds reynolds
story: Mark Reynolds says the pressure is only going to increase on Dundee United as the season nears its end but he’s backed the Tangerines to embrace it by running down leaders Ross County.The Staggies have a five-point advantage on Reynolds  Co. going into United’s final  matches of the campaign and the on-loan Aberdeen man expects the intensity to increase game by game in the race to promotion.He said: “You need to embrace the pressure.“If you are in a team that’s got aspirations to go up and compete in the Premiership you need to deal with pressure.“There are players that don’t deal with that but they don’t play in big teams.“We have a good enough dressing-room and boys who want it and are used to playing under pressure in big games.“Everyone has the capability of thriving in it and that’s what we need to do.“We just need to keep on winning. Ross County will just keep doing what they do but the good thing is we play them twice so it can still be in our hands.“If we beat them in those games then it starts to put the pressure on but we still need them to slip up to make up the eight points.“We’ve left ourselves a lot to do but all we can do is win the games in front of us.“Regardless of who it is, every game will be huge and three points will be massive.”After the disappointment of losing Sunday’s Scottish Cup quarter-final against Inverness, United are targeting an immediateto their recent good league form with  points picked up from their last  available.They take on bottom side Partick Thistle this weekend at Firhill and Reynolds has urged the Terrors to “step up” and grab the three points.He added: “It was disappointing on Sunday and the boys were hurting – it’s right we feel that disappointment and let it sink in before getting back to training yesterday and then focus on the league.“We realise that was a chance to get in a semi-final but the next  games will be like cup finals.“There will be pressure, teams will try to stop us, they’ll make it horrible and we’ll be a scalp.“Teams will want to take points off us but we need to deal with that, step up and find ways to beat them.“If we keep winning then the pressure will increase and increase and it’ll get harder and harder but we need to deal with that.“We need to step up and,we do that, then we’ll have a good chance.”After a testing double header against Inverness Caley Thistle last week with a league win followed by that cup defeat, Reynolds expects the Highlanders to be a handful for their semi-final opponents – whether it’s this weekend’s opponents Partick or Premiership Hearts.He said: “Inverness are a big physical team – they put the ball up the park and play off the back of it and they have good players in amongst that.“Last Tuesday I thought we stood up to that and we won more balls, picked up more seconds and did enough to keep them out.“We didn’t do that on Sunday, we were second to too many balls.“Inverness can do that to teams. They will cause problems.”Reynolds, meanwhile, is happy to see no astroturf surfaces on the horizon after missing recent away trips to Queen of the South and Falkirk on physio’s orders.“That’s the last game on plastic pitches so, unless we go to the play-offs and have to play on one it’ll be fine.“It was just too early, that’s me not long back from a cruciate ligament injury so the advice from the physios was not to play on it and not risk it.“They were the guys that got me back so it would be daft not to listen to them.”

title: former dundee united defender harry souttar called into australian squad
story: Former Dundee United defender Harry Souttar has been called into the Australia U  squad.The -year-old, who is on loan at Fleetwood Town from current employers Stoke City, has accepted a call-up for Australia’s Olympic qualication squad for their training camp in Malaysia and qualiers in Cambodia.Souttar has already represented Scotland at U  and U  level and, along with brother John, is poised to be the first Scottish siblings to play for dferent countries.John made his international debut last year after Hearts boss Craig Levein warned Scotland risked losing him to Australia because he was eligible to play for the Socceroos.Harry had previously insisted it was his dream to play for Scotland.He#s eligible to play for Australia through his mother, who was born in Australia.He stressed two years ago during Scotland U ’s Elite Round qualiers in Czech Republic he was desperate to play for his country.He said: “My ambition has always been to play for Scotland. Who knows, maybe one day I will partner John at the centre of defence for Scotland.“My aim is to try to get myself established in English football and then see what happens.”But Socceroos boss Graham Arnold, who is also in charge of the U  side, insists he’s delighted to have persuaded the former Tangerines and Ross County stopper to follow in the footsteps of Hibs winger Martin Boyle and pledge their future for Australia.The Aussies were alerted to Souttar’s availability by his Stoke City team-mate Adam Federici.Arnold said: “When you look at Harry and his size, he is a beast. However, he is also very good on the ground, too, with his feet and we will take a good look at him.”

title: if they werent there already it is must win time for dark blues
story: Before I start, let me open my big book of cliches and get some of them out of the way.First off the bat, in defence of this piece, cliches are only cliches because they are, generally, true.And it is true that Dundee are about to enter a period of games, some of which are must-win, and most of which are must-not-lose, which could define their season.Before the Dark Blues enter into the post-split realm of six-pointers, though, they must navigate five more tough Premiership fixtures.They will be in for some real battlesthey are to pick up points but they have fighters in their squad now which will give the Dee hope they can do it.No one less so than manager Jim McIntyre. He has marshalled a slight upturn in fortunes in recent weeks which has only been offset by the improved form of their relegation rivals Hamilton Accies and St Mirren, also.However, for Macca, it won’t be job done until Dundee are mathematically safe.And that is a long way off, as they sit in the relegation play-off place, three points behind Accies and only one ahead of the Buddies.Tonight, the Tele takes a look at the Dark Blues’ run-in to the split to see where they can pick up much-needed points.Dundee v Hearts # Saturday, March One of Dundee’s four wins this season, and their only one against a team which currently occupies the top six, came at Tynecastle at the end of January.That - success in Gorgie, coupled with the Jambos’ recent struggles – they are without a win in their last four league outings – will give the Dark Blues confidence going into Saturday’s clash at Dens Park.However, the Dee have only won once at home all season and need that to changethey are to have any hopes of staying in the ision.It’s must-win, for me, and I think they will rise to the occasion.Verdict: Three points.Dundee v Celtic # Sunday, March A game in which Dundee will not be judged on come the end of the season but one,they keep it tight at the back, could see them sneak a valuable point.However, I fancy Celtic to go on a really good run as they look to wrap up eight titles in a row under new manager Neil Lennon.They’ll have too much.Verdict: No points.St Mirren v Dundee # Saturday, March One word. Ten letters. Hyphenated. Six-pointer.If the teams go into this one still practically neck and neck, which I expect they will, a win would be extremely valuable for both.However, I feel, with the enormity of the occasion, they will cancel each other out in Paisley.Verdict: One point.St Johnstone v Dundee # Wednesday, April The Dee and Saints have had some tasty encounters in recent seasons and this one should be no dferent with both teams likely to still have plenty to play for.St Johnstone may still be in the mix for the top six while Dundee’s situation is self-explanatory.I fancy the Dark Blues for this one, they play better on the road and have more to lose than the Perth men.Verdict: Three points.Dundee v Aberdeen # Saturday, April You have to go back to November  for the last time Dundee got a win of any sorts against the Dons.That’s a run of  games without a win, with  losses in a row.That run has to end at some point, so I’ll back the Dee for a hard-earned draw.Verdict: One point.Total points: Eight points.That would leave Dundee with  going into the split and, you would like to think, put them in a decent position to stay up. That is, depending on how Hamilton and St Mirren get on with their fixtures .Hamilton – Motherwell , Hearts , Kilmarnock , Livingston , St Mirren .Verdict: Five points.St Mirren – Kilmarnock , St Johnstone , Dundee , Celtic , Hamilton .Verdict: Eight points.That would leave Hamilton level and St Mirren a point behind Dundee.

title: pals make meat loaf themed coffin to bid farewell to dundee entertainer marc
story: Friends of a Meat Loaf-loving entertainer came together to make sure he was given a fitting final farewell.Marc Kingston died suddenly last month at the age of , having had cancer.Born in Peterborough, he had lived in Dundee for more than  years and was a well-loved performer and DJ known as Marc Meat Loaf, who hosted events in the city.This week his friends met at Dundee Crematorium to make sure the performer received a fitting send-off.Marc arrived in a custom- made coffin painted with Meat Loaf’s Bat Out Of Hell album cover and driven in a flame-effect hearse. vw, px"   vw, px"   vw, px"  He was a huge fan of Meat Loaf, whose hits include I’d Do Anything For Love and Two Out of Three Ain’t Bad.The song Objects In The Rear View Mirror was played as guests left the service. Allan Middleton, who had known Marc for  years, helped to organise the funeral.The bespoke hearse was gted by Allan’s brother Angus’s company, Hearses Are Us, and the coffin was made by a company in England.Allan said: “Marc had seen the car in storage, he had admired it on several occasions and we just thought he liked it so it would be nicewe could use it rather than just a normal hearse.“The wake was in the Ambassador, which was close to his heart because he had done a lot of charity work and things there.“Affertons Funeral Care were brilliant. It was very important that he got a real send-off.”Allan said Marc was a generous man and was always looking to help other people.Marc was also well-known for his talented singing and was ruthless at school with those who he didn’t think were up to much – eventhey did go on to have particularly good careers.Tributes after sudden death of Marc, , one of Dundee#s #great entertainers#" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp tributes-after-sudden-death-of-marc--one-of-dundees-great-entertainers embed # secretisjMwEdx" data-secret"isjMwEdx" width"" "" title"#Tributes after sudden death of Marc, , one of Dundee#s #great entertainers## # Evening " frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"Allan said: “He did do a bit of opera when he was younger.“It was a part of him that Dundee didn’t know much about. These secrets came out at the crem. Fiona Riddle was the celebrant. She was fantastic. She went out of her way to make sure it was personalised.“In his first band at school, Marc threw out one of the singers because he thought he was talentless. That gentleman was Andy Bell of Erasure.”A fundraiser is to be held at the end of this month to help pay for the costs of the funeral and the coffin. Any money left over will go to Ninewells Cancer Campaign.Allan added that Marc loved his job and would often say he “couldn’t have a better way of le, I’m so lucky”.

title: the broons and oor wullie are 83 today take our quiz to find out which character you are most like
story: Jings! Today is the rd anniversary of Oor Wullie and The Broons’ first appearances in The Sunday Post’s Fun Section!First brought to le by Dudley D. Watkins on March  , Wullie is the fearless leader of his gang of Fat Boab, Soapy Soutar and Wee Eck, regularly giving local bobby PC Murdoch the run around.A  survey voted Wullie ‘Scotland’s Favourite Son’, beating William Wallace, Sean Connery and Rabbie Burns in the top four – and it’s easy to see why.Wullie#s popularity is perhaps as high as its ever been. title: Campaigners press on with vision for Inverness park
story: CAMPAIGNERS hoping to transform a historic Inverness park into a vibrant green space are pressing on with their vision, despite suffering a setback.The Northern Meeting Park Group hopes to transfer ownership of the venue in Ardross Street from Highland Council to a community-run organisation in a bid to enable greater public access and breathe new le into its dilapidated buildingsBut its application for a pound, grant to prepare a business plan and carry out surveys has been turned down by the Scottish Land Fund.Following feedback, however, it is now preparing to submit another application in May and is hoping for more positive news.It is also planning to open the usually locked park gates to the public for one week at Easter and another week in the school summer holidays.It is a repeat of a successful two-week trial opening last summer when hundreds took up the chance to enjoy the space for ious uses including family outings, outdoor office meetings and picnic lunches.Leading campaigner Jon Ford hopes to encourage greater use and activities during the opening weeks taking place April ndash and July ndash.ldquoThis year, we also want people to let us knowthey want to form a programme of events and we can seeit is something we can put on, he said.ldquoIf people are out and about in the park there might be a shinty game going on, for example, or a pipe band.Another possibility might be a Teddy bearsrsquo picnic.The group is also in talks with the Care and Learning Allianceabout future possibilities to use the location for childcare provision .In addition, discussions have taken place with the Calman Trust a young peoplersquos service offering housing support, training, employment opportunities, cooking services, about serving refreshments.Jaci Douglas, Calarsquos chief executive, said during discussions with the community over a year ago, flexible and accessible childcare was identied as one of the needs in the area along with a possible use for the park space.ldquoWe have been working closely with the Northern Meeting Park Group on how best to meet that aspiration, she said.ldquoAs an early years charity, Cala is well placed to work with partners to provide a quality early learning and childcare service and we are really excited about the opportunity to do that in close collaboration with the community group, Highland Council and Highland Le Highland as well as with local parents although itrsquos still at the early planning stages. ldquoFriday  Mar  : PM

title: Candlelight tribute for Highland musician
story: A SOPRANO singer has paid tribute to her ldquospecial friend who inspired her to perform a candlelit concert to raise pound for a cancer care charity.Liz McLardy laid on an evening of music and song for Maggiersquos Highlands to show her admiration to staff who lted the spirits of her close friend Helen Sproston in the final days of her le.Mrs Sproston, a -year-old artist and musician who played alto saxophone in the Bonny Vista Social Club, and the Highland Swing band, would have been parted from her beloved Tibetan terrier called Mac had Maggiersquos not allowed friends to bring the dog in for visits while she was being treated at neighbouring Raigmore Hospital.The concert, called Baroque by Candlelight, in which Ms McLardy performed with pianist Tonya Clement and James Ross on clarinet, was held at St Johnrsquos Church in Inverness on February .Poignantly, Mrs Sproston passed away on the same day.Ms McLardy said: ldquoHelen was special. She was just so full of le. She did all sorts of outrageous things like climbing Mont Blanc and she travelled a lot.ldquoShe was a good artist and musician and she loved her little dog. She was unique. Yoursquod never have believed she was in her seventies.Mrs Sprostonrsquos ex-sister-in-law Kay Hall, with whom she attended Altrincham Grammar School in Cheshire, and had held a close bond as the pair married twin brothers, said Mrs Sproston has a son, Stuart, who lives in Barcelona. Her late husband Ron died several years ago.Paying her own tribute, she said: ldquoHelen was a free spirit and a very determined woman. Some people would say she was stubborn and that helped with the diagnosis. She was determined to make best use of the time that she had left.Bonny Vista Social Club guitarist Pete Gavin said he enjoyed Helenrsquos ldquohard-wit and her stoic approach to living and dying.He said: ldquoA couple of us in the band are aware of our own mortality for ious reasons and Helen was a good example for us because her attitude was very much like lsquoitrsquos time for the last song and Irsquom okay with thatrsquo.Fellow band members made a music recording for her, which she wanted to be played at her funeral.She also recorded a few final words which were edited into the track, thanking friends for all their love and good wishes and paying special thanks to the exceptional buddy who ldquosneaked in the GTs during visits.Then the music fades out with her laughter, Helenrsquos parting gt.Friday  Mar  : PM

title: Date set for Highland air traffic controllers strike
story: Air traffic controllers working for Highlands and Islands Airport Limitedare set to strike on April , affecting operations at Inverness Airport as well as in Dundee, Wick, Kirkwall, Sumburgh, Stornoway and Benbecula.Members of the Prospect union will also take action short of a strike between April and August , in a continuing disagreement over their pay offer for -.This will include instruction to work to rosters an overtime ban and withdrawal of goodwill though Prospect says it will seek to agree a protocol with Hial to ensure cover for emergency incidents.David Avery, Prospect negotiations officer, said: ldquoProspect members have agreed to delay any strike action until after the Scottish school holidays have concluded."Our members do not want to stop their friends and neighbours visiting their families during the school holidays.ldquoI urge Hial and Scottish ministers to use the additional time members have given them to bring forward real proposals to resolve the dispute rather than the same offer which has already been rejected twice.Friday  Mar  : PM

title: Demolition of Eastgate Hostel to start soon
story: EVERY effort will be made to keep disruption to a minimum during the long-awaited demolition of an eyesore in Inverness city centre.Work is set to begin on Monday to take down the scaffolding and frontage of the former Eastgate Hostel which has been a blot on the landscape since being gutted by a blaze in April .Inverness city centre manager David Haas said representatives from Highland Council and the Inverness Business Improvement District have been liaising with the agents to work out a programme to ensure the work happens with the least disruption.There would be a temporary narrowing of the thoroughfare to enable the work to be carried out as quickly and effectively as possibly.ldquoWe are working closely with the business community so they understand the need for the works and that we are taking steps to minimise the disruption so as not to prejudice theof their businesses, Mr Haas said.Businesses would still be able to welcome people through their doors.ldquoAs a member of the public you will be able to walk up and down unhindered, he stressed.Talks have also taken place to ensure access for emergency services and deliveries.ldquoEveryone will understand this is an important moment for the High Street and the city, he said. ldquoWe want to give the opportunity to take the building down as quickly and efficiently as possible.The demolition is expected to take  weeks. The plan is for each stone at the front to be marked and set aside for reuse in the rebuild which has now been approved.ldquoI am very pleased that at long last we are going to see activity which is positive and aon the High Street to a usable site in that area, Mr Haas said.ldquoWe are all conscious we have to maintain a proper service to the public. We will not lose sight of that.ldquoThe agents and the contractor are very committed to getting this job done to the highest professional standard.The demolition follows a long-running campaign by the Inverness Courier which ensured the story remained in the headlines.Friday  Mar  : PM

title: Eastgate road closed as hostel demolition work begins
story: Motorists are being advised that Eastgate inInverness will be closed at its junction with Crown Road to its junction with Inglis Street from today until Friday.The closure is to allow demolition work to be carried out at the former Eastgate Hostel building which starts this week, more than five years after the fire that left it gutted.Pedestrian access remains open and access for emergency services and delivery vehicles will be at the discretion of the works contractor.Friday  Mar  : PM

title: Firms are urged to prepare for Brexit
story: BUSINESSES in the Highlands and Islands are not doing enough to prepare for the impact of Brexit, Highlands and Islands Enterprisehas warned.More than two-thirdsof firms who took part in the agencyrsquos latest business  survey in September and October highlighted Brexit as one the main risks they face, with only  per cent believing it posed no risk to their business.Despite this, the survey showed that only  per cent of firms have a plan in place to help them prepare for Brexit, and a fthrecognise that they need to develop a plan.Carroll Buxton, HIErsquos director of regional development, said: ldquoWhile there is still a great deal of uncertainty about how Brexit will affect businesses in the region, some are already taking steps to prepare, and we would encourage others to do so.ldquoThere is help available on the Prepare for Brexit website and from our own website. Through these, businesses can access expert advice to help them plan, including a handy -point Brexit checklist.More than a thirdof businesses that took part in the survey were trading internationally, but respondents had mixed views on the importance to their business of access to the European Single Market. Just over halfregarded this as important while  per cent said it is not important. However, a higher proportionconsidered the single market important to the Scottish economy overall.The free movement of people across the EU was also viewed as important to the Scottish economy by  per cent of respondents, yet only two in fivefelt it was important to their own business.In addition to questions on Brexit and international trade, the business  survey covered other core issues such as economic confidence, business performance and optimism.Almost two thirdssaid they were confident in the regionrsquos economy and  per cent were optimistic about their own performance and prospects.Friday  Mar  : PM

title: Inverness College UHI lecturers on strike again
story: COLLEGE lecturers are on strike today after pay talks failed to produce any agreement.Members of the EIS Further Education Lecturersrsquo Association in Inverness have joined colleagues across Scotland in striking, with another strike set for March .It follows two one-day strikes earlier this year in pursuit of a cost of living pay increase.Picket lines were seen outside Inverness College UHI at Inverness Campus.Talks aimed at averting the strikes broke down without a resolution, leaving representatives for colleges exasperated, according to the Colleges Scotland Employersrsquo Association.John Gribben, the associationrsquos director of employment services, said: ldquoThe Scottish Government has made it clear that there is no more money for lecturersrsquo pay and colleges have to find the pay deal on offer by making cuts.ldquoIf there were any more money available, our priorities would be for additional investment in enhancing studentsrsquo experiences and on further improving college campuses.Friday  Mar  : PM

title: Inverness West residents asked to give their views
story: People living in the Inverness West ward of Highland Council are being invited to take part in two consultation events focussing on the main objectives for the area.Feedback from a similar event last year will be provided and members of the community will be able to see what progress has been made on a range of priorities.Residentsrsquo views on the Riverside Way project, progress with pedestrian crossings over the A, parking and the forthcoming West Link Phase  are very welcome as are any other areas of interest in the ward.In addition there will be drawings and further information on the West Link Phase , with staff available to answer questions.Councillor Graham Ross said: ldquoWe had a great response last year to our ward priority list and members of the community engaged very constructively in telling us about dferent issues and concerns, and suggesting how problems can be tackled."We look forward to sharing the progress made and to hearing of any fresh priorities for the ward. I would encourage as many people as possible to take up this chance to get involved and come along to either of the sessions.Both drop-in sessions will take place on Wednesday, March .The first is from pm to pm at the Bught Stop and the next is from pm-pm in Charleston Academy.Friday  Mar  : PM

title: Keep Safe scheme signs up new Highland sites
story: FRIGHTENED people seeking refuge now have more safe zones in which to get support in Nairn.Police Scotland and the I Am Me charity have welcomed new members to the arearsquos Keep Safe network, which gives people a place to gothey feel frightened, distressed or have been the victim of crime.Nairn Citizens Advice Bureau has joined the initiative, which is delivered in partnership between I Am Me and Police Scotland.The Keep Safe project aims to help people with a disability, feel safe within their community.I Am Me is a community partnership charity developed in Renfrewshire, to raise awareness of Disability Hate Crime.Gill Maclean, manager of Nairn Citizens Advice Bureau, said: ldquoWe are delighted to have been approved as a Keep Safe space and are keen to do all we can help vulnerable people feel safer and, therefore, more likely to venture out into the town.Inspector Judy Hill told the Courier: ldquoThis initiative aims to help vulnerable members of our communities, including the elderly and the disabled, to feel safe and know where to go for help and assistance should they require it.ldquoAll Keep Safe places are approved by Police Scotland.ldquoSometimes due to disability or age-related illness, people can easily become disorientated, lost or become confused, especially in and around unfamiliar surroundings.ldquoKeep Safe can offer a reassurance that there is somewhere people can seek assistancerequired.For more details about the scheme, go online at www.iammescotland keep-safe about-keep-safe Friday  Mar  : PM

title: My Ness art is approved
story: Three residents and Balleary Community Council failed to meet the deadline, although the planners did consider the community councilrsquos objection despite it being late.The artwork, My Ness, was approved under delegated powers, much to the surprise of some city councillors. Delegated powers meant that the application, from Highland Council, was considered by officials and not elected councillors.My Ness is a curved wall sweeping up and over the water which can be used as a seat, a walkway or a viewing .The concerns of the community council and the three iniduals included the impact on wildle and habitats, the deep piling required and possible pollution during construction.Cllr Ken Gowans said: ldquoThis is very disappointing as there are many unanswered questions that that could have been addressed at the planning committee. There are still concerns regarding the future of the fishermanrsquos hut, erosion of the river bank and where the displaced water will go in high water conditions.Cllr Bill Boyd said some people were not behind My Ness, which was to replace the highly controversial tilting pier artwork earmarked for the riverbank at Eden Court until it was ditched two years ago after a public furore. He said there was a question mark over the future of Inverness Angling Clubrsquos hut currently on the site.Zosia Fraser, chairwoman of Balleary Community Council, said: ldquoI think the fair and democratic way of dealing with this would be in open debate.Friday  Mar  : PM

title: New viewing platforms for Inverness riverside
story: A NEW series of "people perches" are to be installed along the River Ness to let people "engage" with the water ndash as a row continues over how plans for a more major piece of waterside art were approved.An artistrsquos impression shows the Rest Space to be sited in Bank Street, opposite the Mercure Hotel, as a set of steps leading to a fenced  over the river.One of several planned for theof the water it is currently in storage, with plans for its installation next month.Designed by Glasgow-based design practice Dress for the Weather it says on its website: "Rest Spaces is one of a series of art initiatives to encourage people to experience and engage with the river as it flows through the city.ldquoIt will encourage people to stop and enjoy the river in a iety of ways: to perch, to explore, to bask, to gather."Councillor Isabelle MacKenzie, chairwoman of the city of Inverness arts working group, which is overseeing the wide-ranging public art programme of which Rest Spaces is one part, said she thought it was ldquorather magnicent.Adding that, cumulatively, the artworks being created along the riverside would make walking in the area a more interesting experience she said: "There might well be some detractors but we are all iniduals."Councillor Ken Gowans, who was a vocal critic of the previous "tilting pier" proposals shelved several years ago, said he was more relaxed about the Bank Street installation."It will be in a very busy and popular location, especially with tourists, and I suspect it will add some interest to that part of the river," he said.Their remarks were made as other councillors continued to voice anger over revelations that the larger scale curving walls artwork proposed for a site close to the Ness Islands has been nodded through by planning officers rather than being put before elected members.Previously called The Gathering Place and My Ness, but referred to as My River Ness in the recently approved application, this artwork involves two crescent-shaped walls curving out from opposite sides of the river.Having been approved by officers under delegated powers councillors have reportedly been told there is now no way to call it in to the planning committeeNess-side SNP councillor Ron MacWilliam said he is set to meet with Inverness city centre manager David Haas over the issue and has called for a special meeting of the city of Inverness area committee."The natural urban environment is a key asset for Inverness and shouldnrsquot be degraded by development where it can be avoided," he said."The commitment by the previous council to spend on the original Gathering Place design, whilst not to everyonersquos pleasure, was based on an economic impact assessment which has never been revised to reflect the new location and design."Common sense tells you that not a soul will visit Inverness to view this utterly boring creation."He added: "As things stand it appears that as a member of the Inverness city committee, a trustee of the Inverness common good fund and member of the south planning applications committee I, and therefore the people I am elected to represent, have not been involved in the decision-making."Inverness West councillor Bill Boyd, who also sits on the planning committee, said he has written to officers to complain about the way the application has been dealt with.However Councillor Graham Ross, depute provost for Inverness, said it was his understanding that the application had been advertised following normal procedures and had failed to attract enough objections to require it to go to committee."The decision to approve was then taken under delegated powers, which means it met with all the planning regulations," he said.Friday  Mar  : PM

title: Second term for Inverness tourism business improvement district
story: Businesses have voted in favour of the Visit Inverness Loch Ness Tourism Business Improvement Districtcontinuing for a second term and a further five years, up to March , .Ballot papers were issued in January to  eligible voters and the count was held today with the result declared at Eden Court. businesses voted lsquoYesrsquo against  businesses which voted lsquoNorsquo.The BID area covers the Highland Council wards of Aird and Loch Ness, Inverness West, Inverness CentralInverness Ness-side, Inverness Millburn, Culloden and Ardersier and Inverness South.Friday  Mar  : PM

title: Smoking not wanted at Invernesss Victorian Market
story: Smokers could soon be made unwelcome around the entrances to Invernessrsquos historic Victorian Market as part of a drive to smarten up the appearance of the shopping arcade.The market itself is officially a smoke-free zone, but two letters sent out to traders asking them not to light up around the entrances have had no effect, it was reported at a meeting of the tradersrsquo association recently.Now market manager Jo Murray is investigating whether it would be legal for the smoking bins currently placed at the entrances to be removed in the hope that this will discourage smokers from congregating there.The meeting heard that among the smoking ldquoculprits at the Church Street entrance to the market are patrons of the neighbouring Market Bar, which shares an access close with the Victorian Market.Mrs Murray admitted: ldquoUnfortunately nothing can be done at the Market Bar entrance as it is private.ldquoHowever, I am checking with the fire service to ensure there is no legislation preventing the fire bins at other entrances being removed.ldquoDropped cigarette butts might become a problemthere are no bins, but litter wardens can fine offenders.The tradersrsquo association meeting agreed that removing the smoke bins at the entrances might help improve the image of the market.It was also agreed that all future Victorian Market literature will also declare it a smoke-free zone.Friday  Mar  : PM

title: sponsored tired of waiting weeks for appointments welcome to aberdeens newest walk in beauty salon
story: Fed up trying to book a nail, lash or brow appointment months in advance so you can get it at a time to suit you  Well, now there’s a solution, thanks to one of Aberdeen’s newest beauty salons.Lash and Lush opened its doors last month and for co-owner Jenna Young, it was vital that the salon suited its clients’ needs, not the other way round. vw, px"  “I’ve been a working mum for the past  years and it’s been so hard to get appointments, unless I booked weeks and months ahead of time.“But even then, with kids your schedule can be unpredictable so that always wasn’t the best way to do things.“I also thought that it would be good for a salon to be open on a Sunday, because people tend to have a bit more time on Sundays.”And in December Jenna decided it was time to make her wishes a reality for other women in Aberdeen.Just over a month later Lash and Lush was up and running. vw, px"  Open six days a weekpeople can just turn up and get treatments.“We don’t take appointments, it’s walk in only, which means you don’t need to wait weeks for an available space.”The team of four highly experienced beauty therapists offers nails , eyelash extensions and volumising, and eyebrow waxing, threading, tinting and henna brows. vw, px"  “Henna brows are a natural way to create a new shape of an eyebrow, or to enhance eyebrows that are pale or have gaps.“And until the end of the month, you can get henna brows for just £.”Jenna added: “Each member of the team focuses on dferent treatments, but every one of them works hard to give customers the look they want.”Lash and Lush is open from am until pm on Tuesdays and Wednesdays and pm on Thursdays and Fridays. On Saturdays they open at am and close at pm and between am and pm on Sundays.Find out more about Lash and Lush on their Facebook page.

title: heres what you need to know about aberdeens new garden waste charge1
story: An annual fee of £ is to be introduced in Aberdeen for the uplt of garden waste.The proposal was passed by Aberdeen City Council at the budget meeting on Tuesday.As a result, an annual fee of £ will be introduced in June for garden waste.A statement by Aberdeen City Council said: #The details have not yet been agreed and there is some work to be done before the charge can be implemented.#We expect that the charge will be implemented later this year.#We will take the opportunity to learn from other councils who have successfully implemented a charge for garden waste.#Only members of the public who choose to use the service will need to pay the charge, it will not be added to council tax payments.As the local authority is required to provide a free food waste collection, those who only use their brown bin for food waste will not be charged for it to be picked up.For those who do not want to pay, garden waste can either be composted at home or taken to their local Household Waste and Recycling Centre free of charge.Garden waste includes flowers, grass cuttings, hedge trimmings, leaves, small branches, bark and twigs and weeds excluding Ragwort and Japanese Knotweed.Food waste includes all cooked and uncooked food, dairy and eggshells, meat, fish and bones, fruit and vegetables, bread, cakes, rice, pasta, tea bags, leftovers and out of date food.Items that cannot be put into the brown bin include pet food, household waste, food packaging, plastic bags, oils or liquids, chemicals, large branches, fence , flower pots and seed trays.Bins must be out for collection by am on the scheduled day, with all bins to be closed and no excess left in the street.

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: honours even for red star in argyll derby

The unfortunate Pupils# defender could only ert the ball into the empty net, with McLean waiting on a tap in. The game continued at a frantic pace, however, there was no further scoring in the first half and Star went in with a - advantage.Pupils came out with purpose in the second half as they looked to force themselves back into the game, however, it was a howler from Red Star which allowed them back into the match.A square ball across the back resulted in a mix-up between Star keeper Luke Kalache and defender Ben Forbes which allowed Donald McCallum to prod the ball home from just inside the box and Pupils were back in the game at - with eight second half minutes gone.The home side didn’t recover from this and you could sense a nervousness that gave the visitors plenty encouragement. The equaliser arrived with  minutes remaining when good play from Pupils down the right by Soudan saw him get a low cross in which was met by the on-rushing run of Ryan Deans and he finished well to level the score at -.This set up a frantic finish and both sides could have nicked it towards the end. story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowShinty in Mid Argyll has lost one of its great stalwarts with the passing of John Crawford of Ardrishaig after a short illness.John, aged , died in Mid Argyll Hospital on the evening of Thursday February .John was born and brought up in Minard in Argyll. He was a former member of shinty#s South of Scotland area executive council and did a lot of work for the Referees’ Association.He was probably best known for his work with young players in Mid Argyll, organising qualying tournaments of the Aviemore Indoor Sixes tournament for many years. He also served on their committee for many years.John had served as a policeman for a short time before working in the quarry at Furnace, then going on to be a very well-known driver with Gleaner Oils, which supported many of his shinty activities with young players in Argyll.John was a great organiser and acted as goal judge in a number of senior shinty finals including the Glasgow Celtic Society Cup and notably the Camanachd Cup Final in Inverness when Gordon MacIntyre of Oban Camanachd scored his famous winner at the Bught Park.John apparently retrieved the ball from the net and lobbed another onto the park for the re-start before presenting the goal-scoring ball to Gordon after the match.John is survived by his brother Jim who played for Glasgow Police and he was pre-deceased by his we Donella. title: a picture of the past written in argylls records
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAt least until Elon Musk builds his time machine, the vast archives held in Argyll are the best way to get an idea of le in the region#s past.A Lochgilphead audience got a flavour of some of the material within two of Argyll#s most extensive and fascinating collections of documents when a roadshow arrived in town to showcase the #Written in the Landscape# project.At Lochgilphead Community Centre, archivist Jen Young outlined the type of archives held by the Live Argyll trust for Argyll and Bute Council including title deeds, personal correspondence, educational records and the history of societies and organisations.Jen has had the task of uncovering and cataloguing  dferent collections of records from landed estates and businesses across Argyll and Bute going back hundreds of years.Co-presenting the event was Hannah Baker, an archivist working on the Written in the Landscape project within the Argyll Papers archive # the documents of the Dukes of Argyll and Argyll Estate dating back to the th century.Within this rich deposit lies a vast source of information. Documents such as rent records, estate census papers, military papers, letters, maps and legal documents can offer a glimpse into the lives of people who lived across Argyll.The two-year Written in the Landscape project is set to wind up in July this year and has entailed cataloguing and digitising the Argyll Estate and other records to make them more accessible to the public.As Hannah and Jen travel round Argyll on their tour, the intention is to offer a local flavour from the archives aimed at each venue.For the Lochgilphead workshop on February , Jen and Hannah presented such erse items as #registers of the poor# and burgh court rolls from Lochgilphead, th century wage books from Kilmory Estate alongside military commission documents from the th century and a  map of the proposed Crinan Canal, surveyed by John Rennie.Each record offers a dferent insight among a treasure trove of detail.The Lochgilphead presentation followed a similar event in Campbeltown in January. For more information on the Argyll and Bute records, contact archives@liveargyll.PICS:Jen, left, and Hannah with some of the records on display in Lochgilphead. aArchivetalkA  letter from Neill Malcolm of Poltalloch offering to call up tenants to defend Crinan Bay against #the enemy# # presumably the French. aArchivetalk

title: ayr bids fond farewell military
story: NewsAyr bids fond farewell as military funeral held for soldier Jock McKelvieAyr High Street came to a standstill as Staff Sergeant Jock was taken on his final journey.ShareByAyrshire Post:,  MAR NewsJocks coffin is carried from the Aud Kirk "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAyr came to a reverential standstill for the military funeral of Staff Sergeant John ‘Jock’ McKelvie, writes Edwin Lawrence. Shoppers stopped in their tracks and shopkeepers stood on their doorsteps to honour an Ayrshire soldier. Police sealed off the High Street to cars as the cortege arrived at the Kirk Port entrance to the Auld Kirk. The silence was broken only by the lament of a lone piper as Jock’s family filed their way into church. Jock’s coffin was carried into a packed service by men of the Scottish and North Irish Yeomanry. His coffin was draped in a union flag and on top were his cap, belt, his campaign medals and a wreath. A dozen colleagues in the firing party formed a guard of honour after the coffin had passed under the  lych gate. Jock, , lived in Dundonald with second we Gigliola, better known as Julie. And he ran a log and firewood business, as well as being a yeomanry reservist. He was laid to rest with full military honours at Drongan where he spent his boyhood and where parents Dan and Rita live. The father-of-two died six days after his armoured car overturned at the Catterick Garrison in Yorkshire on January . Among the mourners in the Auld Kirk was Colonel John Dalrymple Hamilton, who was representing Prince Charles. Provost Helen Moonie of South Ayrshire Council also attended the service. And there was military top brass from both regiments in which Jock served –the Royal Scots Dragoon Guards and the Scottish and North Irish Yeomanry. Other regiments represented included the Royal Engineers, the Royal Artillery, the Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers and the Le Guards. Members of the Army Cadet Force were also present to pay their respects. Jock was  years in the Royal Scots Dragoon Guards, rising to be a Challenger tank commander. He survived tours of duty in Iraq, Kuwait and Kosovo, only to die in a training exercise. Auld Kirk minister Rev David Gemmell described how John McKelvie ‘grabbed le by the throat’ from his earliest days. He wasn’t much of a scholar at Drongan Primary and Auchinleck Academy, but he knew every creature that ran, crawled, swam or flew in the countryside. And a love of the great outdoors was a huge part of his le – whether it was fishing, playing rugby, ski-ing or mountain biking.  He and we Julie were fond of dogs, and Julie taught her big action man how to ride a horse, said the minister. Major Richard Boyle of the Royal Scots Dragoon Guards read the lesson - ‘To every thing there is a season’ from Ecclesiastes. There were hilarious army anecdotes from best buddy JR Ewing, telling how they had shot at each other - with paintballs. J R also mentioned how when Jock was rebuked by a French officer in Kosovo, the big man pointed to his Royal Scots Dragoon Guards cap badge – a French eagle with the word Waterloo underneath. J R, his voice breaking, concluded by saying: “He was the best soldier I ever served with and my best friend.” Former RSDG officer Will Galbraith highlighted Jock’s pride in his regiment, his family and his friends. He said: “He had a strong sense of honour, of right and wrong, and would always stand up for the underdog.” Will said: “He was a big man, with a big voice and a big heart – a big character. But when you really got to know him, he was a big softie – although you wouldn’t tell him that. You had to be aware of those big hands.” Army chaplain Rev Duncan Macpherson said there were bound to be feelings of frustration, anger and regret at the way John McKelvie died. He hoped these would be resolved, adding: “He was someone who was thoroughly tested, who rose to the challenge and who was a thoroughly professional soldier. He was passionate about vehicles and made sure his was ready for any task.” Lt Colonel Toby Gaddum, commanding officer of the Scottish and North Irish Yeomanry, led the congregation in the regimental prayer. Rev David Gemmell brought the church service to an end by poignantly reciting “We Let You Go’. The poem ends: “We love you, we miss you, we want you to be happy. Go safely, go dancing, go running home.” A collection at the end of the service raised vital cash for the Ayrshire Yeomanry Families Fund. Jock was laid to rest at Drongan Cemetery, where a guard of honour fired three volleys from their rles.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnPrince CharlesRoyal Scots Dragoon GuardsSouth Ayrshire CouncilMiddle EastArmed forcesRoyal FamilyLove and romanceDundonaldAyr NewsAyr

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: college staging wine fuelled feast
story: NewsCollege staging wine-fuelled feast as job cuts loomLeaked emails tell of lavish bash at cash-strapped Ayrshire CollegeShareByStephen Houston:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR News"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCollege bosses have defended holding a celebration to honour their success amid a climate of drastic job cuts and cash problems. Ayrshire College supremos and invited senior staff will stage a sit-down feast later this month to mark five years since its formation. The dinner for  will also include free wine after a sponsored deal by college chairman Willie Mackie. Leaked emails state the claim the college is “now regarded as one of the most successful colleges in Scotland.” But our inside source said: “It adds insult to injury that this celebration is being held less than one week before the final jobs structure is issued to staff. “It is in extremely poor taste given the circumstances of potential job losses due to lack of funds.” Evening classes are having to be cancelled so the event can be staged at the Kilmarnock campus on March . Retiring principal Heather Dunk is also to be honoured during the evening. Chairman Willie Mackie said: “She has made a signicant contribution to Ayrshire for over  years.” Ms Dunk retired on February , leaving an impending restructure which will cost jobs. A consultation ends tomorrowand it has emerged the Private Finance Initiative which built the Kilwinning campus is a huge drain on funds. An email which Ms Dunk sent to staff in January read: “We need to make signicant savings to be financially sustainable due to the costs associated with the PFI, unfunded national bargaining costs and the increasing costs of pensions, utilities and other services. I am very disappointed that an organisational review is necessary, it is not what I want to be focused on in my last weeks as principal. “However, we must manage within the financial allocation we receive in this very dficult fiscal climate.” Under the consultation, one of the four vice-principals would be axed, three directors culled, heads of learning cut from  to nine, and three marketing coms staff would go. Also at risk of the chop are two posts within estates as well as a shake-up of duties among departments. The board of management will approve the final structure and staff impacted will get a severance package. Ayrshire College acknowledged finance was a major challenge for all Scottish colleges but said the dinner costs were met by sponsorship. A spokeswoman said: “Our main financial challenge for the year ahead is to meet the costs associated with the Kilwinning PFI Campus, national bargaining costs and the increasing costs of pensions, utilities and services. “While the Scottish Funding Council has agreed to provide further strategic funds to help manage these rising costs, the college still requires to make signicant savings to secure its financial sustainability and jobs for the future. “We are, therefore, considering proposals for an organisational review. “All staff are aware of the challenges the college faces, and have contributed to a consultation regarding potential efficiencies and opportunities for income generation. “We have just passed our five-year anniversary as Ayrshire College, and have planned an event, ‘Celebrating Five Years of Success. It is important to recognise this milestone and celebrate success – for learners, staff, the college and the region. “We are mindful of the costs of holding such an event and so have secured full sponsorship.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnUniversities and CollegesAyr NewsAyrEducationKilmarnockSchoolsKilwinning
